Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Some crowns below pit site from avalanche mitigation work prior to opening day.

Many days of stagnant high pressure air mass with inversions in valleys and relatively warmer temperatures at elevation. Notable weak layer at 26cm is stubborn, but planar w energy when it fails; found this widespread on northerly slopes 7-8200 feet. Also, two buried surface hoar layers near surface to keep an eye on as more snow arrives.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug by Zach Scheunemann and Griffin Dittmar in a closed area within ski area boundary.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in below treeline avalanche path. We also did 2 Loaded PST tests. 10cm of an artificial slab that was 4f-4f+ hard after 1 hr of sitting. Both tests resulted in a slab fracture failure 30cm into the cut. 2x +10cm PST 30/100 SF @ current surface.

In first rise above Lake on Lazy Boy. Previous wind loading observed from Westerly. Storm Cycle occurred in last 24 hours and including within last 6. Observed size 1-2 on Northern aspects. PST Test: Block slid off when touched. Temp profile with too not-yet-calibrated therms. Difficult travel through coastal spooge. Pit done by Drew Copeland and Matt Casson

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Töluvert frost og heiðskír himinn. Við göngu að gryfju var snjór mjúkur, allt að 30-50 cm skóför. Púðursnjór frá síðustu viku. Snjór alveg þurr og engin skel ofan á. Gryfja var í 280 m hæð rétt utan og ofan við Hjallaskóg ofan bæjar. Ekkert brot í snjó, hvorki við göngu né skóflupróf. Snjór virðist stapill.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Wide spread near surface facets. Little change in past week. This could make an interesting layer if it snows again.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: December seasonal profile 2020-11-19 MFcr starting to break down. Resistance profile shows variabilty but for practical purposes this is one layer. No concerns with it yet. Will monitor decomposition.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug on slightly windpacked crest of the spur above Kumatoshi, just between ridge and treeline, 10m beyond ski area boundary when hiking up from gondola. ENE slopes are loaded and I confidently assume that these adjacent loaded faces have a similar snowpack with slightly lower density and ~1.5x depth, more below ridge tops. No stability test done, however when digging pit shearing the 2 obviously layers with shovel felt resistant planar that may fail after hard hits from shoulder but probably produce no result. This was a quick pit before dropping center line off ENE summit face. Jumped off a cornice onto described loaded slope, no cracking or movement. These slopes are very stable.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This put had likely been wind loaded from the first snow of the year as the base was very deep. The upper layers seemed to be fairly representative of the area.

Surface scoured and 6-8" sastrugi visible near pit location, but pit was sheltered by a line of trees and was not scoured. Pit was in a typical spot for early season snow assessment. No collapsing or cracking in area.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Rain to 2500' yesterday at the tail end of the storm. Pit was at the bottom of a slope with well-developed runnels. Surprising to see two wet layers deep in the pack, below thick dry layers.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank; Cracking; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Slide involving new snow in adjacent gully of similar aspect.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Heavy snowfall overnight and continuing as moderate - light snow throughout the day. 20201112 rain event layer at bottom of pack does not fully cover ground in places so no planar surface for any sort of deep slab avalanche, however may be different up high. 2 min pit in bank above Furano ropeway carpark, spent little time looking at grain size, type and did not stability test. Still not really enough snow for avalanches over the elevation of the ski area. Snow almost twice as deep at top of ski area as you would expect.
Snowpack, while still a bit cohesive, is showing signs of faceting out.

Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Collapsing, localized; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: HS-U-R3-D2-O 1000' wide, up to 300' vertical, and 2' average crown height. Avalanche failed on buried SH from 11/19, and stepped down to facets at the ground in some pockets on the slope. There were a ton of tracks adjacent to the avalanche, so it was tough to say whether the avalanche failed naturally or was skier-triggered.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Snowpit location was almost a due south, but also in a location that was partially shaded by some old growth whitebark pine trees.
Some surface hoar observed today in upper Sheep Creek, though not quite as abundant as in upper Pebble Creek the day before (about 1km away as the crow flies to the west). Slightly more surface wind effect in upper Sheep Creek.

- steep scree chute - SP result @ 34 was below a 3cm upper crust, layers within the MFcr were inconsistent

heather ground. Sheltered location by band of trees. No humphing or signs of instability leading to the site but winds whipping up snow transport at ridge top. Minor cracking around skiis when cresting out of trees at higher elev where terrain presents itself to winds. CTM15RP@72; CTM18SP@53 FC 1mm on top of K CR.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This pit was a few hundred feet downhill from an avalanche, which likely occurred a few days earlier during a significant loading event. On the failure layer, it was difficult to tell if there were facets due to wind loading in the pit. We continued to tap after the full propagation and did not have any other failures.

Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Had snowed approximately 75cm in recent days. M-FC was weak and breaking down, facets above crust rounding and gaining strength. Snowpack had good strength at this location but steeper nearby north facing terrain had a natural avalanche from harder crust and more wind loading.
1-3mm graupel dispersed in the bottom 0-5cm.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, widespread; Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: break between storms... clouding up through the day. Recent Avalanches from 11/8 and 11/9 appeared to be releasing on the facets on the ground. Avalanches releasing region wide between elevations 4500 feet to 2500 feet. Sizes from D1-2. Skied Presidents ridge keeping slope angles below 30 degrees.
